body.div:
Such was the history of my beloved cotta
gers. It
struck
^
impressed
me deeply, – and
^
prom
it fr
I learned
from it
^
^ the views
of social
life which
it developed
to admire
their virtues & to deprecate the vices of mankind.
But crimes were distant But
a A s yet I looked
upon crime as a distant evil;
but
for
bene
volence& generosity were ever present
before me – and
I
^
ardently
' longed
^
desired
to make one
^
inciting in me to desire to become an actor in the
busy scene where so many admirable
qualities were called forth and displayed.
But I in giving the histor an account
of the progress of my intellect s , I must not
omit a circumstance that took
which occurred
place in the beginning of the month
of August of
that
the same
year.
One night during my accustomed
visit to the neighbouring wood where
I collected my own food and brought
home firing for p my protectors, I found
on the ground a leathern portmanteau
containing several articles of dress & some
books. I se eagerly seized the prize &
returned with it to my hovel. The books
were fortunately written in the language
the elements
of which
I had learned at the cottage; they consisted
of "Paradise Lost" — a volume of Plutarchs
lives and the
s S orrows of Werter – And these
I
^
was
delighted
in
the
possess
in ion g
of these treasures
which
X
gave me
infinite
extreme
delight ^
I could now continually study
and
occupy exercise
my mind upon
^
the m se
histories when my
friends were employed in their ordinary
concerns occupations . I can hardly describe to you the
effect
that
of
these books had upon me produced . They pro
duced in me an infinity of new images & ideas
that sometimes raised me to extacy but oftenor more
frequently
sunk me to the lowest dejection. In the
Sorrows of Werter besides the interrest of its
simple and affecting story so many opinions are
canvassed and so many lights thrown upon what
had
^
hitherto
been
to me hitherto
dark
obscure
subects that I found
^
in
it
a never end source of speculation. & astonishment. The
gentle and domestic manners it described com
bined with lofty sentiments, and feelings
^
which had for their object something out of self
accor
ded well with my experience among my pro
tectors.
^
and with the wants which were for ever alive within my own bosom.
But I thought Werter himself a more
divine being than I had ever beheld,
–
or imagined.
His cha
racter contained no pretention but it sunk
deep – for he thought The disquisitions upon death
and suicide gave were calculated to fill me
with
astonishment
wonder.
– I did not pretend to
enter into the merits of the case yet I
e i nclined towards the opinion of the Hero
whose extinction I wept although I did
without
precisely
not understand ing it. As I read however I
applied much
^
personally
to my
self
^
and
own feelings & condition
I found my
self
at the same tim e similar yet
^
at the same time
strangely unlike the beings concerning whom
I read and who were my
to
to
of
whose conver
sation I was a listener – I sympathized
I pa with & partly understood them– but
I was unformed in mind. I was dependant
on none, & related to none – "The path of my
departure was free"! and there was none
to lament
my extinction
my annihilation
– My person
was hideous and my stature gigantic – What
did this mean? Who was I? What was I?
Whence
did I come?
What was
my destination? these questions continually recurred but I
was unable to solve them
The volume of Plutarchs lives which I
possessed contained the histories of the first
founders of the ancient republics– This book
had a far different effect upon me from
the letters Sorrows the letters of Werter. I lea r ned
from
that
his Werter's g imaginations despondency & gloom; but Plutarch
taught me high thoughts—he elevated me above
m the wretched sphere of my own reflections
to admire & love the heroes of past ages. Yet
Many things I read surpassed my unterstanding
and
knowledge
^
experience
I had a very
t confused know
ledge of kingdoms & wide extents of country
mighty rivers and boundless seas. But I
was perfectly unacquainted with towns &
large
assemblegs
assemblages of men. The cottage
rs were
of my protectors
was
was
the o only school
in
where
which
I had studied human
nature — But this book
threw a new light upon
^
developed new & mightier scenes of action
it I read of men concerned in public
affairs governing their species — an or
masser
c e ring their speceis. I felt the greatest ardour
for virtue rise within me and abhor
rence for vice
as far as I understood it the
signification of those terms relative as they
were only , as I applied them, to pleasure
and pain
^
alone.
.
with
Induced by
these feelings it may be
I was of course led to admire peacable
lawgivers Numa, Solon & Lycurgus more than
Romulus and Theseus. The patriarchal lives
of my protectors
induced
im caused
to a greater degree
these impressions
^
to take a firm hold on my mind
— perhaps if my first
resid
ence
human
introduction
to
intercourse
with
humanity
had been
^
with
made by
a young soldier burning
for glory and slaughter I should have
been imbued with different sensations
But Paradise Lost Excited
in me different and far deeper
sensations
feelings
emotions –I read it as I
did had
read
the
other volumes which had fallen in
to my hands, as a true history. and It
excited
moved
every
feeling
feeling
of wonder and
awe. I deeply lamented the fall
of Adam that
T t he picture of an omni
potent God warring with his crea
tures was capable of exciting – often
I
^
often
referred the several situations
as their similarity struck me to
my own. Like Adam I felt my was
self created but I w apparently
desolate in my situation
as I had been had been
united by no link to any
other being
of the
creation in existence
but
his state was different from
mine in every other respect.
He had come forth from the
hands of God a perfect creature
happy & prosperous
X
guarded by the spe es
pecial care of his
creator.
and
–he was
allow
ed to converse &
acquire knowledge
from beings of a
superior nature
– but I was
wretched helpless and alone. Oft
Many times I considered Satan
as my fitter mate for often
like him when I viewed the
bliss of my protectors the bitter
gall of envy rose within me.
But I would not disturb their
he
Another circumstance
strengthened and confirmed these
feelings. I had soon a Soon
affe af
ter my arrival in the hovel I dis
covered some papers in one of the
pocket
s of the dress
that
which
I had taken
from your study.
I
At
had first
I
had
despised
neglected
them but now that I was able to decypher
the characters in
them
^
which they were written
I began to decypher study them
with diligence. It was your journal of
the four
la months that preceeded
my creation.
It
you minutely des
cribed
^
in it
these papers
every step you took in the
progress of your work; and this
^
history
was
mingled with accounts of domestic
occurences. You doubtless well recollect
these papers– He re they are – Every
thing is
told
related
i in them
^
^ which bears
reference to
my accursed
ori
gin.
& every
the whole detail of that
disgus
ting
circumstance
series of
horrors
disgusting
circumstances which produced it
is set in view;
the minutest description
is given of my
odious & loathsome person.
is X
X given in language
which painted your
own horrors, &has
traced conveyed them to
has rendered mine
ineffaceable.
. I
sickened as I read – the papers. One
Hateful day when I received life, I
exclaimed in agony— Cursed c C reator
Why did you form a monster
so hideous that even you turned
from me in disgust. God in pity made
man beautiful & alluring – I am
more hateful to the sight than
the bitter apples of Hell to the taste
Satan has his companions, fellow
devils, to admire and encourage
him. but I am solitary & detested
Such
^
These
were my reflections in my
hours of despond
e ncy & solitude but
when I contemplated the virtues of
the cottagers. Their amiable & benevolent
dispositions I persuaded myself that
X
X When they
^
should
be
came acquainted with
my admiration of their
virtues
they would pity me and overlook
my personal deformity when they
should know my admiration of
their virtues. Yes I
^
was
mad enough to
^
put
my
trust in my own intentions and to
Could they turn from their door
one however monstrous, who solici
ted their compassion & friendship?
I resolved at least not to despair
but in every way to fit myself
for an interview which would
de s cide my fate. I wish I postponed
this attempt for some months longer for the
importance attached to it
's
success inspired
me with a
^
dread
for it's success
lest it should not succeed
that I in vain endeavoured to
surmount . Besides I found that
my understanding improved so much
with every days experience that
I that I was unwilling to attempt
commence this
attempts
undertaking
untill
a few more months should have
added to my des wisdom
Many Several changes in the mean
time took place in the cottage
the presence of
Maimouna
Safie
diffused
happiness among its inhabitants and
also as I soon perceived more plenty
and I also found that a greater g degree
of plenty
& en reigned there – Felix &
and Agatha spent more time
in amusement
^
and
& conversation they and were now also
assisted in their labours by servants
They
were not
did not appear
rich but they were
contented & happy. Such were their fee
lings
^
were serene & peaceful, while
I
mine
became every day more
unhappy
miserable – encrease of knowledge only shewed
discovered to
me more
plainly
^
clearly
what a wretched outcast
I was. I cherished hope it is true but
it vanished when I beheld my person re
flected
by
in
the
water or even my shadow
in the moonshine —I endeavoured to hush
crush these fears and to fortify myself for the
trial which in a few months I resolved
to undergo; and sometimes I allowed my
thoughts unchecked by reason to ramble
in the fields of Paradise
&
to fan
dared
to fancy amiable & lovely beings
sym
pathizing with my feelings and cheeri
ng my d gloom — Their angelic cont
countenances breathed smiles of
consola
tion — But it was all a dream – No
Eve waited on soothed my sorrows
or shared my thoughts. I was alone.
I remembered Adams supplication to
his creator but where was mine?
He had abbandoned me and in the
bitterness of my heart I cursed him.
Autumn passed thus and
with
surpise & grief I saw the leaves decay
& fall,
And nature again assume
the barren & bleak appearance
it had when I first beheld the
woods and the lovely moon. I
did not heed the
cold
bleakness of the weather
By my consti
tution
I was more fitted
for that
this sufferance
of cold than heat. But my only joys were
were the sight of flowers and birds
and all the gay apparel of summer
but
and
when those deserted me & the
days became shorter I turned with
more attention towards the cottagers
Their happiness was
^
not decreased by
T t
he absence of summer – They loved
and sympathized with one another
and the ir
happiness
^
joys
depending on
each other were not
hurt
interrupted
by the
casualties that took place around
them — The more I saw of them
the greater became my desire to
claim their protection & kindness.
My heart yearned to beco be
^
known and
loved
by the se amiable creatures to see
their sweet looks directed towards
me in kindness – I dared not think
that they would turn them from me
with disdain or horror – The poor
that stopt at their door were
never driven away – And I I asked
it is true for greater treasures
that a little food or rest I required
kindness & sympathy but I
^
did
not
believe my self utterly unworthy
of it
Chap. 7
The
season
winter
advanced and it was now about a
and an entire revolution of the
year
^
seasons had taken place
since I awoke into life.– and I then at
that time My attention
^
at this time
was now solely
directed towards my plan of introducing
myself into the cottage of my protectors. I revol
ved many projects but that on which I
finally fixed was to enter their dwelling when
the blind old man
was
should be
alone. My voice
although harsh had nothin k g terrible in
it. and I had sagacity enough to discover
that the unnatural hideousness of my person
was the chief object of horror am with those
who had formerly beheld me:–my voice al
though harsh, had nothing terrible in
it. I thought therefore that if in the absence
of his children I could gain the goodwill
of the old De Lacey I might by his means be
tolerated by the my younger protectors.
One clear One day when the sun
shone on the red leaves that strewed
the ground, and all diffused cheerfulness
although it denied warmth Maimouna Safie
Agatha and Felix set out on a long country
walk and the old man at his own desire
was left alone in the cottage. When his chil
dren had departed he took up his guitar &
played ver several mournful but sweet
airs:
that I had seldom
^
more sweet & mournful that I had ever heard him play
before. At first his countenance was illumi
nated with pleasure but as he continued thought
fullness and sadness succeeded and laying down
the instrument he sat absorbed
in reflection.
My heart beat quick. This
was the hour & moment of trial
which
was to
^
would
decide my fea hopes
or I quitted my hovel with trem The
servants of the cottage were gone
to a neighbouring fair:– All was
silent in and around the cottage
It was an excellent opportunity
yet when I
rose
proceeded
to execute my plan
my limbs failed me, and I sunk
to the ground. Again I rose and
with with
exerting all of the firm
n ess
^
of which I
was master of removed the planks
which I had placed before my
hovel to conceal my retreat – The
fresh air revived me and with
renewed
determination I approach
ed the door of the cottage. I knock
ed – "who is there?" said the old
man– "come in"— I entered – "Pardon
this intrusion" said I– "I am a
traveller, in want of a little
rest. and you would greatly oblige
me if you would allow me to
remain a few minutes before
your fire." "Enter" said De Lacey &
I will try in what manner I can re
lieve your wants– but unfortunately
my children are
out
from home,
and
^
as I am blind
I am afraid therefore I shall find it
difficult to procure food for you"–
"Do not trouble yourself, my kind
host," I replied, I have food, it is warmth
and rest only that I need.–I sat down
and a silence ensued; I kn o e w very
well that every minute was precious
to me yet I remained irresolute
^
in
what
to say
manner to
comemmence
the interview
when the old man
began
^
addressed me
–"By
your language St
^
r anger, I suppose you
are my countryman, are you french?"
"No," replied I but I was educated by a
french family and understand that
language only. I am unfortunate and
a Str I am now going to claim the
protection of some friends, whom I sincerely
love
but
and of whose favour I have
some hopes." "Are these Germans"–
Asked
De Lacey – know"No –They are french –But let
us change the subject –I am an unfortu
nate& deserted creature. I look around and
I have no relation or friend
–
^
on earth – The
se kind
^
amiable
people to whom I go, have never seem
me and know little of me. I am full
of fears, for if I fail there, I am an
outcast in the world for ever."
Do not despair, said the old man.
To be friendless is indeed to be unfortu
nate: but
^
the hearts of
men are when unpre
judiced by obvious self interrest, are full
of brotherly love and charity. Rely therefore
on your hopes and if these dispositions
of your friends are kind these friends
are good and amiable – do not
fear despair for your
They are kind– I answered– They are the most
amiable excellent creatures in the world but unfortu
nately they are prejudiced against me. I
have good dispositions –I love virtue and
detest knowledge, –my life has been hitherto
harmless & in some degree beneficial
but a fatal prejudice clouds their eyes
and where they ought to see a feeling
and kind friend, they behold only a detes
table monster.–
That is indeed unfortunate, replied
De Lacey– but if you are really blameless can
not you undeceive them?
This is That is
the task that
what I
am
shall
goin
^
am about
endeavouring
to undertake
that task
— said I "And it is on that
account that I feel so many overwhelming
terrors—I love these friends tenderly; for many
months I have
^
for many months
unknown to them been
for many months in the habits of daily kindness towards them,
but they believe that I wish to injure
them and it is that prejudice which
I wish to over come.
Where do these friends reside, said de
Lacey — N
Near here.
I replied
^
on
this spot.
[
The old man
paused a moment and then continued
If you will unreservedly confide to me
the particulars I perhaps may be of use
in undeceiving them. I am blind and
cannot judge of your countenance but
there is somthing in your words
that which
persuades me that you are sincere.
I am poor and an exile, but it
will afford me true pleasure to of be
in any way
service able to a
fellow
human
creature.—
Excellent man – exclaimed I, I
thank you and accept your
^
generous
offer
X
You raise me
from the dust
by this kindess and I trust now that I shall not be driven
from the society & sympathy of my
fellow creatures
Heaven forbid! even if you
are
were
really
criminal for that
not in can only drive you
to desperation and not
reform
^
instigate
you
^
to virtue
—
I also am unfortunate.– I
and my
family have been condemned when
although innocent judge therefore
if I do not sympath feel for your
misfortunes—
How can I thank you, my best &
only benefactor – from your lips first
have I heard the voice of kindness
directed towards me –I shall be for
ever grateful and your present
humanity assures me of success with
the friends whom I am on the
point of meeting
May I know the names of and residence
of those friends? asked De Lacey.
I paused — This was the moment
of decision which was to rob me
^
of
or
bestow happiness
^
on me
for ever – I sum
I struggled vainly to find for firmness
sufficient
enough
to answer him – but the effort
destroyed all my remaining stren t gth
& I sank on the a chair & sobbed aloud
At that moment I heard the steps
of my younger protectors— I had not
a moment to lose, but seizing the
hand of the old man I cried– Now
is the time, save and protect me
You and your family are the
friends whom I seek – Do not you
des a
^
e rt me in the hour of trial – ! .–
Great God! exclaimed the old
man – Who are you?
At that instan d t
the cottage
door opened and Felix, Maimouna
Safie
and Agatha entered – Who can
describe their horro w r
and asto
nishment on beholding
^
me –Agatha
fainted &
Maimouna Safie
unable
to attend to her friend rushed
out of the cottage.– Felix darted
forward and with supernatural
strength tore me from his father
to whose knees I clung –In a
transport of fury he dashed
me to the ground and struck
me voi len lently with a stick
I saw him going to on the point
of repeating the p blow when
overcome by pain and anguish
I quitted the cottage and in the
general tumult, escaped unper
ceived to my hovel.
